title: AnimatedModelFacetExtensions.SetBoneTransformsFast
content:
AnimatedModelFacetExtensions.SetBoneTransformsFast 
SetBoneTransformsFast 
 Set the bone transforms via a fast path.
 OPTIMIZATION: this function sets these properties without comparison or events. Unfortunately, F# forces
 array value equality on us. Because this function elides change detection and thus the equality check, it
 runs much faster than setting the BoneOffsets and BoneTransform properties normally.

title: CoreOperators
content:

 The core operators that come with the Nu Game Engine. 
CoreOperators.($) 
($)

(===) 
CoreOperators.(=/=)

title: CoreOperators.($)
content:
CoreOperators.($) 
($) 
 Sequences two functions like Haskell ($).
 Same as the ($) operator found in Prime, but placed here to expose it directly from Nu.

title: CoreOperators.(===)
content:
CoreOperators.(===) 
(===) 
 Test for object equality.
 Same as the (===) operator found in Prime, but placed here to expose it directly from Nu.

title: CoreOperators.(=/=)
content:
CoreOperators.(=/=) 
(=/=) 
 Test for object inequality.
 Same as the (=/=) operator found in Prime, but placed here to expose it directly from Nu.

title: EffectFacetExtensions.SetEffectDescriptor
content:
EffectFacetExtensions.SetEffectDescriptor 
SetEffectDescriptor 
 When RunMode is set to RunEarly, call this AFTER setting the rest of the entity's properties. This
 is because setting the effect descriptin in RunEarly mode will immediately run the first frame of the
 effect due to a semantic limitation in Nu.

title: EventGraph
content:
EventGraph 
 A functional publisher-neutral mechanism for handling simulation events in Nu.
 Publisher-neutrality means that the user can subscribe to events regardless if the event source exists or not.
 This decouples subscription lifetime from event source lifetime.

title: StaticModelSurfaceFacetExtensions2.TryGetAlbedoImageAssetName
content:
StaticModelSurfaceFacetExtensions2.TryGetAlbedoImageAssetName TryGetAlbedoImageAssetName 
 Attempt to get the currently assigned albedo image asset name, looking it up from metadata when unassigned.
 Useful in editor because oftentimes the only useful identifying information about a static model surface is
 its material assets, particularly its albedo image like so -
 
 for entity in World.getEntities SelectedGroup world do
     match entity.TryGetAlbedoImageAssetName world with
     | ValueSome name when name.Contains "Glass" ->
         entity.SetRenderStyle (Forward (0.0f, 0.0f)) world
     | _ -> ()

content:
Stream.product 
product 
 Combine two streams. Combination is in 'product form', which is defined as a pair of the data of the combined
 events. Think of it as 'zip' for event streams.

title: Stream.sum
content:
Stream.sum 
sum 
 Combine two streams. Combination is in 'sum form', which is defined as an Either of the data of the combined
 events, where only data from the most recent event is available at a time.

title: TmxExtensions.GetImageAsset
content:
TmxExtensions.GetImageAsset 
GetImageAsset 
 Get the associated image asset for the given TmxTileset in the specified package.
 If the TmxTileset object has a custom property named "Image" with an asset value like "[PackageName AssetName]",
 it will be parsed to retrieve the image asset. If the custom property is missing, the image asset will be
 inferred from the tile set's image source filename. Throws a TileSetPropertyNotFoundException if the custom
 property "Image" is missing and the tile set's image source filename cannot be inferred.
 Thread-safe.

title: TmxExtensions.GetImageAssets
content:
TmxExtensions.GetImageAssets 
GetImageAssets 
 Get each of the map's tilesets paired with their associated image assets (per the given package).
 Thread-safe.

title: WorldChain.chain
content:
WorldChain.chain 
chain 
 Execute a chain over the given stream.
 Allows each chained operation to run without referencing its source event, and without specifying its event
 handling approach by assuming Cascade.

title: WorldGroupModule.destroyGroupImmediate
content:
WorldGroupModule.destroyGroupImmediate 
destroyGroupImmediate 
 Destroy a group in the world immediately. Can be dangerous if existing in-flight publishing depends on the
 group's existence. Consider using World.destroyGroup instead.

title: WorldGroupModule.destroyGroup
content:
WorldGroupModule.destroyGroup 
destroyGroup 
 Destroy a group in the world at the end of the current update.

title: WorldGroupModule.destroyGroupsImmediate
content:
WorldGroupModule.destroyGroupsImmediate 
destroyGroupsImmediate 
 Destroy multiple groups in the world immediately. Can be dangerous if existing in-flight publishing depends
 on any of the groups' existences. Consider using World.destroyGroups instead.

title: WorldGroupModule.destroyGroups
content:
WorldGroupModule.destroyGroups 
destroyGroups 
 Destroy multiple groups from the world at the end of the current update.

title: WorldGroupModule.renameGroupImmediate
content:
WorldGroupModule.renameGroupImmediate 
renameGroupImmediate 
 Rename a group. Note that since this destroys the renamed group immediately, you should not call this
 inside an event handler that involves the reassigned group itself. Note this also renames all of its
 descendents accordingly.

title: Asset
content:
Asset 
 Describes a game asset, such as an image, sound, or model in detail.

 All assets must belong to an asset Package, which is a unit of asset loading.

 In order for the renderer to render a single texture, that texture, along with all the other assets in the
 corresponding package, must be loaded. Also, the only way to unload any of those assets is to send a package unload
 message to the relevent subsystem. 
Asset.AssetTag 
AssetTag 
Asset.Refinements 
Refinements 
Asset.Associations 
Associations 
Asset.FilePath 
FilePath

title: 'a Asset
content:
'a Asset 
 Describes a strongly-typed game asset, such as an image, sound, or model, in detail.

 All assets must belong to an asset Package, which is a unit of asset loading.

 In order for the renderer to render a single texture, that texture, along with all the other assets in the
 corresponding package, must be loaded. Also, the only way to unload any of those assets is to send a package unload
 message to the relevent subsystem. 
'a Asset.AssetTag 
AssetTag 
'a Asset.FilePath 
FilePath

title: PhysicsMotion.SynchronizedMotion
content:
PhysicsMotion.SynchronizedMotion 
SynchronizedMotion 
 When body transform message comes in from physics subsystem, entity's transform will be set by the game engine.
 When entity's transform is set by the user, body transform message will be sent to physics engine.

title: PhysicsMotion.ManualMotion
content:
PhysicsMotion.ManualMotion 
ManualMotion 
 When body transform message comes in from physics subsystem, entity's transform will not be set by the game
 engine; instead an event will be published. When entity's transform is set by the user, nothing will be sent to
 the physics engine.

title: StructPair<'a, 'b>
content:
StructPair<'a, 'b> 
 A struct-based representation of a pair.
 This type would seem redundant with struct (,) and KeyValuePair, but it's not. This type is unique in that allows
 you to take a reference to its Fst and Snd fields. Unfortunately, there seems to be no way to do that with
 struct (,) or KeyValuePair.
 NOTE: StructPair doesn't allow client assemblies to reference its fields, so it's not properly usable outside of
 Nu's engine code, unfortunately. 
StructPair<'a, 'b>.Fst 
Fst 
StructPair<'a, 'b>.Snd 
Snd

title: World
content:
World 
 The world, in a functional programming sense. Hosts the simulation state, the dependencies needed to implement a
 game, messages to by consumed by the various engine subsystems, and general configuration data. For better
 ergonomics, the World type keeps a mutable reference to the functional WorldState, which is updated by the engine
 whenever the engine transforms the world state.

title: Behavior.constant
content:
Behavior.constant 
constant 
 A behavior that emits a constant value 'k' at all times.
 The output behavior produces values of the same type as the provided constant value 'k'.

title: Behavior.time
content:
Behavior.time 
time 
 A behavior that emits the current 'GameTime' value at each time step.

title: Behavior.timeLoopRaw
content:
Behavior.timeLoopRaw 
timeLoopRaw 
 A time-emitting loop behavior based on the specified 'stride' and 'bounce' parameters.
 The 'stride' parameter represents the duration of each loop iteration.
 The 'bounce' parameter indicates whether the loop will reverse its direction after each iteration.
 The output behavior produces 'GameTime' values indicating the progress within each loop iteration.

title: Behavior.timeSliceRaw
content:
Behavior.timeSliceRaw 
timeSliceRaw 
 A time-slicing behavior that emits 'GameTime' values within the specified time range.
 The 'start' parameter represents the start time of the slice.
 The 'length' parameter indicates the duration of the time slice.
 The output behavior produces 'GameTime' values within the specified time range.

title: Behavior.timeLoop
content:
Behavior.timeLoop 
timeLoop 
 A normalized time-emitting loop behavior based on the specified 'stride' and 'bounce' parameters.
 The 'stride' parameter represents the duration of each loop iteration.
 The 'bounce' parameter indicates whether the loop will reverse its direction after each iteration.
 The output behavior produces normalized values (0.0f to 1.0f) indicating the progress within each loop iteration.

title: Behavior.timeSlice
content:
Behavior.timeSlice 
timeSlice 
 A normalized time-slicing behavior that emits normalized values (0.0f to 1.0f) within the specified time range.
 The 'start' parameter represents the start time of the slice.
 The 'length' parameter indicates the duration of the time slice.
 The output behavior produces normalized values (0.0f to 1.0f) indicating the progress within the specified time range.

content:
Behavior.lerp 
lerp 
 A behavior that produces a value that is linearly interpolated between the values 'a' and 'b' based on the input
 behavior's value (interpreted as a normalized interpolation factor).

title: Behavior.ease
content:
Behavior.ease 
ease 
 A behavior that produces a value that is linearly interpolated between 'a' and 'b' using a custom scaling
 function based on the input behavior's value. The custom scaling function 'scale' should take a pair
 (difference, scalar) and return a value representing the interpolation factor. The output behavior produces
 values of the same type as 'a' and 'b'.

content:

 behavior produces values of the same type as 'a' and 'b'.

title: Modifier.first
content:
Modifier.first 
first 
 Composes the given modifier `mdfr` with the behavior of a pair of type `'a * 'c`.
 The `mdfr` is applied to the first component of the pair, while the second component remains unchanged.
 The output behavior is a pair of type `'b * 'c`, where the first component is the result of applying `mdfr` to
 the first component of the input pair, and the second component is the unchanged second component of the input
 pair.

title: Modifier.second
content:
Modifier.second 
second 
 Composes the given modifier `mdfr` with the behavior of a pair of type `'c * 'a`.
 The `mdfr` is applied to the second component of the pair, while the first component remains unchanged.
 The output behavior is a pair of type `'c * 'b`, where the first component is the unchanged first component of
 the input pair, and the second component is the result of applying `mdfr` to the second component of the input
 pair.

title: Modifier.compose
content:
Modifier.compose 
compose 
 Composes the given modifier `mdfr` with another modifier `mdfr2`.
 The `mdfr` is applied first, and then the result is passed as input to `mdfr2`.

title: Modifier.composeFlip
content:
Modifier.composeFlip 
composeFlip 
 Composes the given modifier `mdfr2` with another modifier `mdfr`.
 The `mdfr2` is applied first, and then the result is passed as input to `mdfr`.

title: Modifier.split
content:
Modifier.split 
split 
 Splits the input into two behaviors and runs the given modifiers `mdfr` and `mdfr2` on each part independently.

title: Modifier.fanOut
content:
Modifier.fanOut 
fanOut 
 Fan-out composition of two modifiers.
 It runs both modifiers `mdfr` and `mdfr2` on the same input behavior and produces a pair of results.

title: Modifier.composeLeft
content:
Modifier.composeLeft 
composeLeft 
 Composes the given modifier `mdfr` with the provided function `f`.
 The `mdfr` is applied first, and then the resulting behavior is mapped using `f`.

title: Modifier.composeLeftFlip
content:
Modifier.composeLeftFlip 
composeLeftFlip 
 Composes the given modifier `mdfr` with the provided function `f`.
 The `mdfr` is applied first, and then the resulting behavior is mapped using `f`.

title: EffectSystem.eval
content:
EffectSystem.eval eval 
 Evaluates an EffectDescriptor, applying the effect if it is still alive, with the following parameters:
   - descriptor: The EffectDescriptor to be evaluated.
   - slice: The Slice to apply the effect on.
   - history: A history of the effect's previous states.
   - effectSystem: The current state of the effect system.
 The function evaluates the EffectDescriptor to determine if the effect is still alive.
 If the effect is alive, it modifies the effectSystem to apply the effect to the given slice.
 If the effect is not alive, it simply releases the effectSystem without applying the effect.

title: EffectSystem.make
content:
EffectSystem.make make 
 Creates a new EffectSystem with the following parameters -
   - localTime: The time basis of the effect.
   - absolute: A flag indicating if the effect is absolute.
   - presence: The presence of the effect.
   - shadowOffset: How far to offset shadows of any billboards.
   - renderType: The render type of the effect.
   - globalEnv: The global environment for the effect.

 OPTIMIZATION: LifeTimeOpt uses GameTime.zero to represent infinite life.
 OPTIMIZATION: doesn't use Liveness type to avoid its constructor calls.
 OPTIMIZATION: pre-computes progress scalar to minimize number of divides.

title: PhysicallyBased.CreatePhysicallyBasedMaterial
content:
PhysicallyBased.CreatePhysicallyBasedMaterial 
CreatePhysicallyBasedMaterial 
 Create physically-based material from an assimp mesh, falling back on defaults in case of missing textures.
 Uses file name-based inferences to look for texture files in case the ones that were hard-coded in the model
 files can't be located.
 Thread-safe if renderable = false.

title: AnimationState
content:
AnimationState

Applies animations over time, queues animations for later playback, mixes (crossfading) between animations, and applies multiple animations on top of each other (layering).

See Applying Animations in the Spine Runtimes Guide.

AnimationState.``.ctor`` ``.ctor`` AnimationState.AssignEventSubscribersFrom AssignEventSubscribersFrom AnimationState.AddEventSubscribersFrom AddEventSubscribersFrom AnimationState.Update Update AnimationState.Apply Apply AnimationState.ApplyEventTimelinesOnly ApplyEventTimelinesOnly AnimationState.ClearTracks ClearTracks AnimationState.ClearTrack ClearTrack AnimationState.SetAnimation SetAnimation AnimationState.SetAnimation SetAnimation AnimationState.AddAnimation AddAnimation AnimationState.AddAnimation AddAnimation AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimation SetEmptyAnimation AnimationState.AddEmptyAnimation AddEmptyAnimation AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimations SetEmptyAnimations AnimationState.ClearNext ClearNext AnimationState.GetCurrent GetCurrent AnimationState.ClearListenerNotifications ClearListenerNotifications AnimationState.ToString ToString AnimationState.TimeScale TimeScale AnimationState.Data Data AnimationState.Tracks Tracks AnimationState.Start Start AnimationState.Interrupt Interrupt AnimationState.End End AnimationState.Dispose Dispose AnimationState.Complete Complete AnimationState.Event Event

title: AnimationState.Update
content: AnimationState.Update Update Increments the track entry TrackEntry.TrackTime, setting queued animations as current if needed.

title: AnimationState.Apply
content:
AnimationState.Apply 
Apply 

            Poses the skeleton using the track entry animations.  The animation state is not changed, so can be applied to multiple
            skeletons to pose them identically.

title: AnimationState.ApplyEventTimelinesOnly
content: AnimationState.ApplyEventTimelinesOnly ApplyEventTimelinesOnly Version of AnimationState.Apply only applying and updating time at EventTimelines for lightweight off-screen updates.

title: AnimationState.ClearTracks
content:
AnimationState.ClearTracks ClearTracks

Removes all animations from all tracks, leaving skeletons in their current pose.

It may be desired to use AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimations to mix the skeletons back to the setup pose, rather than leaving them in their current pose.

title: AnimationState.ClearTrack
content:
AnimationState.ClearTrack ClearTrack

Removes all animations from the track, leaving skeletons in their current pose.

It may be desired to use AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimation to mix the skeletons back to the setup pose, rather than leaving them in their current pose.

title: AnimationState.SetAnimation
content: AnimationState.SetAnimation SetAnimation Sets an animation by name. AnimationState.SetAnimation

title: AnimationState.SetAnimation
content:
AnimationState.SetAnimation 
SetAnimation 
Sets the current animation for a track, discarding any queued animations. If the formerly current track entry was never
            applied to a skeleton, it is replaced (not mixed from).

title: AnimationState.AddAnimation
content:
AnimationState.AddAnimation 
AddAnimation 
Queues an animation by name.

title: AnimationState.AddAnimation
content: AnimationState.AddAnimation AddAnimation Adds an animation to be played after the current or last queued animation for a track. If the track is empty, it is equivalent to calling AnimationState.SetAnimation.

title: AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimation
content:
AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimation SetEmptyAnimation

Sets an empty animation for a track, discarding any queued animations, and sets the track entry's !:TrackEntry.getMixDuration(). An empty animation has no timelines and serves as a placeholder for mixing in or out.

Mixing out is done by setting an empty animation with a mix duration using either AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimation, AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimations, or AnimationState.AddEmptyAnimation. Mixing to an empty animation causes the previous animation to be applied less and less over the mix duration. Properties keyed in the previous animation transition to the value from lower tracks or to the setup pose value if no lower tracks key the property. A mix duration of 0 still mixes out over one frame.

Mixing in is done by first setting an empty animation, then adding an animation using AnimationState.AddAnimation with the desired delay (an empty animation has a duration of 0) and on the returned track entry, set the !:TrackEntry.SetMixDuration(float). Mixing from an empty animation causes the new animation to be applied more and more over the mix duration. Properties keyed in the new animation transition from the value from lower tracks or from the setup pose value if no lower tracks key the property to the value keyed in the new animation.

title: AnimationState.AddEmptyAnimation
content: AnimationState.AddEmptyAnimation AddEmptyAnimation Adds an empty animation to be played after the current or last queued animation for a track, and sets the track entry's TrackEntry.MixDuration. If the track is empty, it is equivalent to calling AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimation.

title: AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimations
content:
AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimations 
SetEmptyAnimations 
            Sets an empty animation for every track, discarding any queued animations, and mixes to it over the specified mix
            duration.

title: AnimationState.ClearNext
content: AnimationState.ClearNext ClearNext Removes the TrackEntry.Next and all entries after it for the specified entry.

title: AnimationState.ClearListenerNotifications
content:
AnimationState.ClearListenerNotifications ClearListenerNotifications 
 Discards all listener notifications that have not yet been delivered. This can be useful to call from an
            AnimationState event subscriber when it is known that further notifications that may have been already queued for delivery
            are not wanted because new animations are being set.

title: AnimationState.TimeScale
content:
AnimationState.TimeScale TimeScale

Multiplier for the delta time when the animation state is updated, causing time for all animations and mixes to play slower or faster. Defaults to 1.

See TrackEntry TrackEntry.TimeScale for affecting a single animation.

title: Bone
content:
Bone Stores a bone's current pose.

A bone has a local transform which is used to compute its world transform. A bone also has an applied transform, which is a local transform that can be applied to compute the world transform. The local transform and applied transform may differ if a constraint or application code modifies the world transform after it was computed from the local transform.

Bone.``.ctor`` ``.ctor`` Bone.``.ctor`` ``.ctor`` Bone.Update Update Bone.UpdateWorldTransform UpdateWorldTransform Bone.UpdateWorldTransform UpdateWorldTransform Bone.SetToSetupPose SetToSetupPose Bone.UpdateAppliedTransform UpdateAppliedTransform Bone.WorldToLocal WorldToLocal Bone.LocalToWorld LocalToWorld Bone.WorldToParent WorldToParent Bone.ParentToWorld ParentToWorld Bone.WorldToLocalRotation WorldToLocalRotation Bone.LocalToWorldRotation LocalToWorldRotation Bone.RotateWorld RotateWorld Bone.ToString ToString Bone.Data Data Bone.Skeleton Skeleton Bone.Parent Parent Bone.Children Children Bone.Active Active Bone.X X Bone.Y Y Bone.Rotation Rotation Bone.ScaleX ScaleX Bone.ScaleY ScaleY Bone.ShearX ShearX Bone.ShearY ShearY Bone.Inherit Inherit Bone.AppliedRotation AppliedRotation Bone.AX AX Bone.AY AY Bone.AScaleX AScaleX Bone.AScaleY AScaleY Bone.AShearX AShearX Bone.AShearY AShearY Bone.A A Bone.B B Bone.C C Bone.D D Bone.WorldX WorldX Bone.WorldY WorldY Bone.WorldRotationX WorldRotationX Bone.WorldRotationY WorldRotationY Bone.WorldScaleX WorldScaleX Bone.WorldScaleY WorldScaleY

title: Bone.UpdateWorldTransform
content:
Bone.UpdateWorldTransform UpdateWorldTransform Computes the world transform using the parent bone and the specified local transform. The applied transform is set to the specified local transform. Child bones are not updated.

See World transforms in the Spine Runtimes Guide.

title: Bone.SetToSetupPose
content:
Bone.SetToSetupPose 
SetToSetupPose 
Sets this bone's local transform to the setup pose.

title: Bone.UpdateAppliedTransform
content:
Bone.UpdateAppliedTransform UpdateAppliedTransform Computes the applied transform values from the world transform.

If the world transform is modified (by a constraint, Bone.RotateWorld, etc) then this method should be called so the applied transform matches the world transform. The applied transform may be needed by other code (eg to apply another constraint).

Some information is ambiguous in the world transform, such as -1,-1 scale versus 180 rotation. The applied transform after calling this method is equivalent to the local transform used to compute the world transform, but may not be identical.

title: IkConstraint
content:
IkConstraint

Stores the current pose for an IK constraint. An IK constraint adjusts the rotation of 1 or 2 constrained bones so the tip of the last bone is as close to the target bone as possible.

See IK constraints in the Spine User Guide.

IkConstraint.``.ctor`` ``.ctor`` IkConstraint.``.ctor`` ``.ctor`` IkConstraint.SetToSetupPose SetToSetupPose IkConstraint.Update Update IkConstraint.ToString ToString IkConstraint.Bones Bones IkConstraint.Target Target IkConstraint.Mix Mix IkConstraint.Softness Softness IkConstraint.BendDirection BendDirection IkConstraint.Compress Compress IkConstraint.Stretch Stretch IkConstraint.Active Active IkConstraint.Data Data IkConstraint.Apply Apply IkConstraint.Apply Apply

title: IkConstraint.Bones
content:
IkConstraint.Bones 
Bones 
The bones that will be modified by this IK constraint.

title: IkConstraint.Target
content:
IkConstraint.Target 
Target 
The bone that is the IK target.

title: IkConstraint.Mix
content:
IkConstraint.Mix Mix A percentage (0-1) that controls the mix between the constrained and unconstrained rotation.

For two bone IK: if the parent bone has local nonuniform scale, the child bone's local Y translation is set to 0.

title: IkConstraint.Softness
content:
IkConstraint.Softness Softness 
For two bone IK, the target bone's distance from the maximum reach of the bones where rotation begins to slow. The bones
            will not straighten completely until the target is this far out of range.

title: IkConstraint.BendDirection
content:
IkConstraint.BendDirection 
BendDirection 
For two bone IK, controls the bend direction of the IK bones, either 1 or -1.

title: IkConstraint.Compress
content:
IkConstraint.Compress 
Compress 
For one bone IK, when true and the target is too close, the bone is scaled to reach it.

title: IkConstraint.Stretch
content:
IkConstraint.Stretch Stretch When true and the target is out of range, the parent bone is scaled to reach it.

For two bone IK: 1) the child bone's local Y translation is set to 0, 2) stretch is not applied if IkConstraint.Softness is > 0, and 3) if the parent bone has local nonuniform scale, stretch is not applied.

title: MathHelper.Lerp
content:
MathHelper.Lerp Lerp Linearly interpolates between two values. This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula: 
value1 + (value2 - value1) * amount
. Passing amount a value of 0 will cause value1 to be returned, a value of 1 will cause value2 to be returned. See MathHelper.LerpPrecise for a less efficient version with more precision around edge cases.

title: MathHelper.LerpPrecise
content:
MathHelper.LerpPrecise LerpPrecise Linearly interpolates between two values. This method is a less efficient, more precise version of MathHelper.Lerp. See remarks for more info. This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula: 
((1 - amount) * value1) + (value2 * amount)
. Passing amount a value of 0 will cause value1 to be returned, a value of 1 will cause value2 to be returned. This method does not have the floating point precision issue that MathHelper.Lerp has. i.e. If there is a big gap between value1 and value2 in magnitude (e.g. value1=10000000000000000, value2=1), right at the edge of the interpolation range (amount=1), MathHelper.Lerp will return 0 (whereas it should return 1). This also holds for value1=10^17, value2=10; value1=10^18,value2=10^2... so on. For an in depth explanation of the issue, see below references: Relevant Wikipedia Article: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_interpolation#Programming_language_support Relevant StackOverflow Answer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4353525/floating-point-linear-interpolation#answer-23716956

title: MixBlend
content: MixBlend Controls how timeline values are mixed with setup pose values or current pose values when a timeline is applied with alpha < 1. MixBlend.value__ value__ MixBlend.Setup Setup MixBlend.First First MixBlend.Replace Replace MixBlend.Add Add

title: MixBlend.Setup
content:
MixBlend.Setup Setup 
 Transitions from the setup value to the timeline value (the current value is not used). Before the first frame, the
                      setup value is set.

title: MixBlend.First
content:
MixBlend.First First

Transitions from the current value to the timeline value. Before the first frame, transitions from the current value to the setup value. Timelines which perform instant transitions, such as DrawOrderTimeline or AttachmentTimeline, use the setup value before the first frame.

First is intended for the first animations applied, not for animations layered on top of those.

title: MixBlend.Replace
content:
MixBlend.Replace Replace

Transitions from the current value to the timeline value. No change is made before the first frame (the current value is kept until the first frame).

Replace is intended for animations layered on top of others, not for the first animations applied.

title: MixBlend.Add
content:
MixBlend.Add Add

Transitions from the current value to the current value plus the timeline value. No change is made before the first frame (the current value is kept until the first frame).

Add is intended for animations layered on top of others, not for the first animations applied. Properties set by additive animations must be set manually or by another animation before applying the additive animations, else the property values will increase each time the additive animations are applied.

title: MixDirection
content: MixDirection Indicates whether a timeline's alpha is mixing out over time toward 0 (the setup or current pose value) or mixing in toward 1 (the timeline's value). Some timelines use this to decide how values are applied. MixDirection.value__ value__ MixDirection.In In MixDirection.Out Out

title: Skeleton.SetSkin
content: Skeleton.SetSkin SetSkin Sets a skin by name (see Skeleton.SetSkin).

title: Skeleton.SetSkin
content:
Skeleton.SetSkin SetSkin

Sets the skin used to look up attachments before looking in the SkeletonData.DefaultSkin. If the skin is changed, Skeleton.UpdateCache is called.

Attachments from the new skin are attached if the corresponding attachment from the old skin was attached. If there was no old skin, each slot's setup mode attachment is attached from the new skin.

After changing the skin, the visible attachments can be reset to those attached in the setup pose by calling Skeleton.SetSlotsToSetupPose. Also, often AnimationState.Apply is called before the next time the skeleton is rendered to allow any attachment keys in the current animation(s) to hide or show attachments from the new skin.

title: Skeleton.GetAttachment
content: Skeleton.GetAttachment GetAttachment Finds an attachment by looking in the Skeleton.Skin and SkeletonData.DefaultSkin using the slot name and attachment name.

title: Skeleton.GetAttachment
content:
Skeleton.GetAttachment 
GetAttachment 
Finds an attachment by looking in the skin and skeletonData.defaultSkin using the slot index and attachment name.First the skin is checked and if the attachment was not found, the default skin is checked.

title: Skeleton.SetAttachment
content:
Skeleton.SetAttachment 
SetAttachment 
A convenience method to set an attachment by finding the slot with FindSlot, finding the attachment with GetAttachment, then setting the slot's slot.Attachment.

See VertexAttachment.ComputeWorldVertices and DeformTimeline.

title: TrackEntry
content:
TrackEntry

Stores settings and other state for the playback of an animation on an AnimationState track.

References to a track entry must not be kept after the !:AnimationStateListener.Dispose(TrackEntry) event occurs.

TrackEntry.``.ctor`` ``.ctor`` TrackEntry.Reset Reset TrackEntry.SetMixDuration SetMixDuration TrackEntry.ResetRotationDirections ResetRotationDirections TrackEntry.ToString ToString TrackEntry.AllowImmediateQueue AllowImmediateQueue TrackEntry.TrackIndex TrackIndex TrackEntry.Animation Animation TrackEntry.Loop Loop TrackEntry.Delay Delay TrackEntry.TrackTime TrackTime TrackEntry.TrackEnd TrackEnd TrackEntry.TrackComplete TrackComplete TrackEntry.AnimationStart AnimationStart TrackEntry.AnimationEnd AnimationEnd TrackEntry.AnimationLast AnimationLast TrackEntry.AnimationTime AnimationTime TrackEntry.TimeScale TimeScale TrackEntry.Alpha Alpha TrackEntry.InterruptAlpha InterruptAlpha TrackEntry.EventThreshold EventThreshold TrackEntry.AlphaAttachmentThreshold AlphaAttachmentThreshold TrackEntry.MixAttachmentThreshold MixAttachmentThreshold TrackEntry.MixDrawOrderThreshold MixDrawOrderThreshold TrackEntry.Next Next TrackEntry.Previous Previous TrackEntry.WasApplied WasApplied TrackEntry.IsNextReady IsNextReady TrackEntry.IsComplete IsComplete TrackEntry.MixTime MixTime TrackEntry.MixDuration MixDuration TrackEntry.MixBlend MixBlend TrackEntry.MixingFrom MixingFrom TrackEntry.MixingTo MixingTo TrackEntry.HoldPrevious HoldPrevious TrackEntry.Reverse Reverse TrackEntry.ShortestRotation ShortestRotation TrackEntry.IsEmptyAnimation IsEmptyAnimation TrackEntry.Start Start TrackEntry.Interrupt Interrupt TrackEntry.End End TrackEntry.Dispose Dispose TrackEntry.Complete Complete TrackEntry.Event Event

title: TrackEntry.ResetRotationDirections
content:
TrackEntry.ResetRotationDirections ResetRotationDirections

Resets the rotation directions for mixing this entry's rotate timelines. This can be useful to avoid bones rotating the long way around when using TrackEntry.alpha and starting animations on other tracks.

Mixing with MixBlend.Replace involves finding a rotation between two others, which has two possible solutions: the short way or the long way around. The two rotations likely change over time, so which direction is the short or long way also changes. If the short way was always chosen, bones would flip to the other side when that direction became the long way. TrackEntry chooses the short way the first time it is applied and remembers that direction.

title: TrackEntry.TrackIndex
content:
TrackEntry.TrackIndex 
TrackIndex 
The index of the track where this entry is either current or queued.

title: TrackEntry.Animation
content:
TrackEntry.Animation 
Animation 
The animation to apply for this track entry.

title: TrackEntry.Loop
content:
TrackEntry.Loop 
Loop 
            If true, the animation will repeat. If false it will not, instead its last frame is applied if played beyond its
            duration.

title: TrackEntry.Delay
content:
TrackEntry.Delay Delay

Seconds to postpone playing the animation. When this track entry is the current track entry, Delay postpones incrementing the TrackEntry.TrackTime. When this track entry is queued, Delay is the time from the start of the previous animation to when this track entry will become the current track entry (ie when the previous track entry TrackEntry.TrackTime >= this track entry's Delay).

TrackEntry.TimeScale affects the delay.

When using AnimationState.AddAnimation with a delay <= 0, the delay is set using the mix duration from the AnimationStateData. If TrackEntry.mixDuration is set afterward, the delay may need to be adjusted.

title: TrackEntry.TrackTime
content: TrackEntry.TrackTime TrackTime Current time in seconds this track entry has been the current track entry. The track time determines TrackEntry.AnimationTime. The track time can be set to start the animation at a time other than 0, without affecting looping.

title: TrackEntry.TrackEnd
content:
TrackEntry.TrackEnd TrackEnd

The track time in seconds when this animation will be removed from the track. Defaults to the highest possible float value, meaning the animation will be applied until a new animation is set or the track is cleared. If the track end time is reached, no other animations are queued for playback, and mixing from any previous animations is complete, then the properties keyed by the animation are set to the setup pose and the track is cleared.

It may be desired to use AnimationState.AddEmptyAnimation rather than have the animation abruptly cease being applied.

title: TrackEntry.TrackComplete
content: TrackEntry.TrackComplete TrackComplete If this track entry is non-looping, the track time in seconds when TrackEntry.AnimationEnd is reached, or the current TrackEntry.TrackTime if it has already been reached. If this track entry is looping, the track time when this animation will reach its next TrackEntry.AnimationEnd (the next loop completion).

title: TrackEntry.AnimationStart
content:
TrackEntry.AnimationStart AnimationStart

Seconds when this animation starts, both initially and after looping. Defaults to 0.

When changing the AnimationStart time, it often makes sense to set TrackEntry.AnimationLast to the same value to prevent timeline keys before the start time from triggering.

title: TrackEntry.AnimationEnd
content: TrackEntry.AnimationEnd AnimationEnd Seconds for the last frame of this animation. Non-looping animations won't play past this time. Looping animations will loop back to TrackEntry.AnimationStart at this time. Defaults to the animation Animation.Duration.

title: TrackEntry.AnimationLast
content: TrackEntry.AnimationLast AnimationLast The time in seconds this animation was last applied. Some timelines use this for one-time triggers. Eg, when this animation is applied, event timelines will fire all events between the AnimationLast time (exclusive) and AnimationTime (inclusive). Defaults to -1 to ensure triggers on frame 0 happen the first time this animation is applied.

title: TrackEntry.AnimationTime
content:
TrackEntry.AnimationTime AnimationTime Uses TrackEntry.TrackTime to compute the AnimationTime. When the TrackTime is 0, the AnimationTime is equal to the AnimationStart time.

The animationTime is between TrackEntry.AnimationStart and TrackEntry.AnimationEnd, except if this track entry is non-looping and TrackEntry.AnimationEnd is >= to the animation Animation.Duration, then animationTime continues to increase past TrackEntry.AnimationEnd.

title: TrackEntry.TimeScale
content:
TrackEntry.TimeScale TimeScale

Multiplier for the delta time when this track entry is updated, causing time for this animation to pass slower or faster. Defaults to 1.

Values < 0 are not supported. To play an animation in reverse, use TrackEntry.Reverse.

TrackEntry.MixTime is not affected by track entry time scale, so TrackEntry.MixDuration may need to be adjusted to match the animation speed.

When using AnimationState.AddAnimation with a Delay <= 0, the TrackEntry.Delay is set using the mix duration from the AnimationStateData, assuming time scale to be 1. If the time scale is not 1, the delay may need to be adjusted.

See AnimationState AnimationState.TimeScale for affecting all animations.

title: TrackEntry.Alpha
content:
TrackEntry.Alpha Alpha

Values < 1 mix this animation with the skeleton's current pose (usually the pose resulting from lower tracks). Defaults to 1, which overwrites the skeleton's current pose with this animation.

Typically track 0 is used to completely pose the skeleton, then alpha is used on higher tracks. It doesn't make sense to use alpha on track 0 if the skeleton pose is from the last frame render.

title: TrackEntry.EventThreshold
content: TrackEntry.EventThreshold EventThreshold When the mix percentage (TrackEntry.MixTime / TrackEntry.MixDuration) is less than the EventThreshold, event timelines are applied while this animation is being mixed out. Defaults to 0, so event timelines are not applied while this animation is being mixed out.

title: TrackEntry.AlphaAttachmentThreshold
content: TrackEntry.AlphaAttachmentThreshold AlphaAttachmentThreshold When TrackEntry.Alpha is greater than AlphaAttachmentThreshold, attachment timelines are applied. Defaults to 0, so attachment timelines are always applied.

title: TrackEntry.MixAttachmentThreshold
content: TrackEntry.MixAttachmentThreshold MixAttachmentThreshold When the mix percentage (TrackEntry.MixTime / TrackEntry.MixDuration) is less than the MixAttachmentThreshold, attachment timelines are applied while this animation is being mixed out. Defaults to 0, so attachment timelines are not applied while this animation is being mixed out.

title: TrackEntry.MixDrawOrderThreshold
content: TrackEntry.MixDrawOrderThreshold MixDrawOrderThreshold When the mix percentage (TrackEntry.MixTime / TrackEntry.MixDuration) is less than the MixDrawOrderThreshold, draw order timelines are applied while this animation is being mixed out. Defaults to 0, so draw order timelines are not applied while this animation is being mixed out.

title: TrackEntry.Next
content:
TrackEntry.Next Next The animation queued to start after this animation, or null if there is none. next makes up a doubly linked list.

See AnimationState.ClearNext to truncate the list.

title: TrackEntry.Previous
content: TrackEntry.Previous Previous The animation queued to play before this animation, or null. previous makes up a doubly linked list.

title: TrackEntry.WasApplied
content:
TrackEntry.WasApplied 
WasApplied 
Returns true if this track entry has been applied at least once.

title: TrackEntry.IsNextReady
content: TrackEntry.IsNextReady IsNextReady Returns true if there is a TrackEntry.Next track entry that will become the current track entry during the next AnimationState.Update.

title: TrackEntry.IsComplete
content:
TrackEntry.IsComplete 
IsComplete 

            Returns true if at least one loop has been completed.

title: TrackEntry.MixTime
content: TrackEntry.MixTime MixTime Seconds from 0 to the TrackEntry.MixDuration when mixing from the previous animation to this animation. May be slightly more than MixDuration when the mix is complete.

title: TrackEntry.MixDuration
content:
TrackEntry.MixDuration MixDuration

Seconds for mixing from the previous animation to this animation. Defaults to the value provided by AnimationStateData AnimationStateData.GetMix based on the animation before this animation (if any).

The MixDuration can be set manually rather than use the value from AnimationStateData.GetMix. In that case, the MixDuration can be set for a new track entry only before AnimationState.Update is first called.

When using AnimationState.AddAnimation with a Delay <= 0, the TrackEntry.Delay is set using the mix duration from the AnimationStateData. If mixDuration is set afterward, the delay may need to be adjusted. For example:

entry.Delay = entry.previous.TrackComplete - entry.MixDuration;

Alternatively, TrackEntry.SetMixDuration can be used to recompute the delay:

entry.SetMixDuration(0.25f, 0);

title: TrackEntry.MixBlend
content:
TrackEntry.MixBlend MixBlend

Controls how properties keyed in the animation are mixed with lower tracks. Defaults to MixBlend.Replace.

Track entries on track 0 ignore this setting and always use MixBlend.First.

The MixBlend can be set for a new track entry only before AnimationState.Apply is first called.

title: TrackEntry.MixingFrom
content: TrackEntry.MixingFrom MixingFrom The track entry for the previous animation when mixing from the previous animation to this animation, or null if no mixing is currently occurring. When mixing from multiple animations, MixingFrom makes up a linked list.

title: TrackEntry.MixingTo
content: TrackEntry.MixingTo MixingTo The track entry for the next animation when mixing from this animation to the next animation, or null if no mixing is currently occurring. When mixing to multiple animations, MixingTo makes up a linked list.

title: TrackEntry.HoldPrevious
content:
TrackEntry.HoldPrevious HoldPrevious

If true, when mixing from the previous animation to this animation, the previous animation is applied as normal instead of being mixed out.

When mixing between animations that key the same property, if a lower track also keys that property then the value will briefly dip toward the lower track value during the mix. This happens because the first animation mixes from 100% to 0% while the second animation mixes from 0% to 100%. Setting HoldPrevious to true applies the first animation at 100% during the mix so the lower track value is overwritten. Such dipping does not occur on the lowest track which keys the property, only when a higher track also keys the property.

Snapping will occur if HoldPrevious is true and this animation does not key all the same properties as the previous animation.

title: TrackEntry.Reverse
content:
TrackEntry.Reverse 
Reverse 
            If true, the animation will be applied in reverse. Events are not fired when an animation is applied in reverse.

title: TrackEntry.ShortestRotation
content:
TrackEntry.ShortestRotation ShortestRotation

If true, mixing rotation between tracks always uses the shortest rotation direction. If the rotation is animated, the shortest rotation direction may change during the mix.

If false, the shortest rotation direction is remembered when the mix starts and the same direction is used for the rest of the mix. Defaults to false.

title: TrackEntry.IsEmptyAnimation
content: TrackEntry.IsEmptyAnimation IsEmptyAnimation Returns true if this entry is for the empty animation. See AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimation, AnimationState.AddEmptyAnimation, and AnimationState.SetEmptyAnimations.

title: TransformConstraint
content:
TransformConstraint

Stores the current pose for a transform constraint. A transform constraint adjusts the world transform of the constrained bones to match that of the target bone.

See Transform constraints in the Spine User Guide.

title: Math.Lerp
content:
Math.Lerp Lerp Linearly interpolates between two values. This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula: 
value1 + (value2 - value1) * amount
. Passing amount a value of 0 will cause value1 to be returned, a value of 1 will cause value2 to be returned. See Math.LerpPrecise for a less efficient version with more precision around edge cases.

title: Math.Lerp
content:
Math.Lerp Lerp Linearly interpolates between two values. This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula: 
value1 + (value2 - value1) * amount
. Passing amount a value of 0 will cause value1 to be returned, a value of 1 will cause value2 to be returned. See Math.LerpPrecise for a less efficient version with more precision around edge cases.

title: Math.LerpPrecise
content:
Math.LerpPrecise LerpPrecise Linearly interpolates between two values. This method is a less efficient, more precise version of Math.Lerp. See remarks for more info. This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula: 
((1 - amount) * value1) + (value2 * amount)
. Passing amount a value of 0 will cause value1 to be returned, a value of 1 will cause value2 to be returned. This method does not have the floating point precision issue that Math.Lerp has. i.e. If there is a big gap between value1 and value2 in magnitude (e.g. value1=10000000000000000, value2=1), right at the edge of the interpolation range (amount=1), Math.Lerp will return 0 (whereas it should return 1). This also holds for value1=10^17, value2=10; value1=10^18,value2=10^2... so on. For an in depth explanation of the issue, see below references: Relevant Wikipedia Article: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_interpolation#Programming_language_support Relevant StackOverflow Answer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4353525/floating-point-linear-interpolation#answer-23716956

title: Math.LerpPrecise
content:
Math.LerpPrecise LerpPrecise Linearly interpolates between two values. This method is a less efficient, more precise version of Math.Lerp. See remarks for more info. This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula: 
((1 - amount) * value1) + (value2 * amount)
. Passing amount a value of 0 will cause value1 to be returned, a value of 1 will cause value2 to be returned. This method does not have the floating point precision issue that Math.Lerp has. i.e. If there is a big gap between value1 and value2 in magnitude (e.g. value1=10000000000000000, value2=1), right at the edge of the interpolation range (amount=1), Math.Lerp will return 0 (whereas it should return 1). This also holds for value1=10^17, value2=10; value1=10^18,value2=10^2... so on. For an in depth explanation of the issue, see below references: Relevant Wikipedia Article: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_interpolation#Programming_language_support Relevant StackOverflow Answer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4353525/floating-point-linear-interpolation#answer-23716956

title: Math.ApproximatelyEqual
content:
Math.ApproximatelyEqual 
ApproximatelyEqual 

            Approximates equivalence between two single-precision floating-point numbers on a direct human scale.
            It is important to note that this does not approximate equality - instead, it merely checks whether or not
            two numbers could be considered equivalent to each other within a certain tolerance. The tolerance is
            inclusive.

            inclusive.
